oai_dc:dc.dc:title: On the dangers of conflating strong and weak versions of a theory of consciousness
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Michel, Matthias
Lau, Hakwan
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Consciousness
Neural correlates of consciousness
Integrated information theory
Consciousness
neural correlates of consciousness
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Some proponents of the Integrated Information Theory (IIT) of consciousness profess strong views on the Neural Correlates of Consciousness (NCC), namely that large swathes of the neocortex, the cerebellum, at least some sensory cortices, and the so-called limbic system are all not essential for any form of conscious experiences. We argue that this connection is not incidental. Conflation between strong and weak versions of the theory has led these researchers to adopt definitions of NCC that are inconsistent with their own previous definitions, inadvertently betraying the promises of an otherwise fruitful empirical endeavour.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Philosophy and the Mind Sciences; Vol. 1 No. II (2020): Special Issue: The Neural Correlates of Consciousness
